1090410.1007/10904.1574-1451Journal of Inorganic and Organometallic Polymers and MaterialsJ Inorg Organomet Polym1574-14431574-1451Springer USNew Yorks10904-015-0267-526710.1007/s10904-015-0267-5ArticleSynthesis, Crystal Structures, Photocatalysis for Rhodamine B Degradation of a Organobismuth (V) Dithiocarbamate Polymer [PhBiS2CN(C2H5)2Cl]nCuiLiansheng1MengXiangmin1FanYuhua1LiXin1BiCaifeng1e0000 0001 2152 3263grid.4422.0Key Laboratory of Marine Chemistry Theory and Technology, Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry and Chemical EngineeringOcean University of China266100QingdaoShandongPeople’s Republic of China+8653266781932bicaifeng301@163.com1182015112015256149014943172015285201531720151182015© Springer Science+Business Media New York 20152015Abstract

A organobismuth (V) dithiocarbamate complex, [PhBiS2CN(C2H5)2Cl]n has been synthesized and characterized by IR, element analysis, 1H NMR and X-ray diffraction single crystal analysis. The complex crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system, space group P2(1)/c. is coordinated by two sulphur atoms, a carbon atom from benzene ring and two chlorine atoms. The complex leads to one-dimensional zigzag chain structure by a bridging chlorine atom to link metal ions and two adjacent chains are bridged by C–H⋯C interactions. Furthermore, the photocatalytic experiments of the complex on degradation of rhodamine B (RhB) manifest that the complex is good candidate for the photocatalytic degradation of RhB.

Bismuth complex chemistry has attracted significant interest not only due to the low cost and high abundance of bismuth resources on Earth, but also because this element and its compounds find many practical applications in pharmaceutics and medicine [1], catalysis [2], and as precursors for ceramics, superconductors and semiconductors, ionic batteries materials, photocatalysts, etc. [3–5]. For dithiocarbamate ligand with strong coordination ability. It can almost coordinate with all of the transition metal, so a large number of transition-metal complexes with dithiocarbamate have been synthesized and structurally characterized, and a few reports have appeared on the synthesis and structures of the bismuth complexes with dithiocarbamate [6–10]. However, the chemistry of organobismuth (V) complexes with dithiocarbamate has been scarcely studied.

So it causes our interest in organobismuth (V) complexes. A organobismuth (V) complex has been synthesized by the reaction of Ph3BiCl2 with Na(S2CNR2) and characterized by IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, 1H NMR and single crystal X-ray diffraction. In addition, photocatalytic experiments of the complex on degradation of rhodamine B (RhB) were also investigated.

ExperimentalMeasurement and Reagents

All solvents were pretreated to get rid of the water before using. Sodium diethyldithiocarbamate dihydrate and triphenylbismuth dichloride were purchased from TCI and the other chemicals were produced in China.

Infrared spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a Nicolet 170SX spectrometer in the 4000–400 cm−1 region. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a model 2400 Perkin Elmer analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on an AVANCE III (600 MHz) spectrometer. The X-ray diffraction data were collected on an Enraf–Nonius CAD-4 X-ray single-crystal diffractometer. The UV spectra were recorded on an Avatar 360 FT-IR spectrometer in the range 190–600 nm in methanol solution. The fluorescence spectra were recorded on an F-4500 spectrophotometer. Electrochemical study used the CHI650D electrochemical analyzer.

SynthesesSynthesis of [PhBiS<sub>2</sub>CN(C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>5</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Cl]<sub>n</sub>

Sodium diethyldithiocarbamate dihydrate (0.342 g, 2.0 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (20 mL) and Triphenylbismuth (0.511 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in THF (20 mL)and added. The mixed solution was stirred at 25 °C for 24 h. The mixture was dried in vacuo and extracted by ethanol (10 mL) and dichloromethane (10 mL). The extract was concentrated to 5 mL and crystallization for 2 weeks at 25 °C gave colorless single crystals. Elemental Anal Calc (%) for the complex : C 28.10, H 3.20, N 2.98. Found (%): C 28.06, H 3.15, N 2.95. IR (KBr, cm−1): 1595 (m), 1465 (s), 1246, 1130 (m), 958, 549, 441 (s). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 600 MHz) δ (ppm): 1.46 (d, 6H), 2.84 (d, 4H), 7.85 (m, 5H).

X-ray Structure Determination

The single crystal with dimensions of 0.23 × 0.15 × 0.08 mm was mounted on an Enraf–Nonius CAD-4 X-ray single-crystal diffractometer. All data were collected at 293 (2) K with a graphite-monochromatized MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using a ω − 2θ scan mode. 2969 Reflections intensities with I > 2σ(I) was considered to be observed and used in the subsequent refinements. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [11]. The non-hydrogen atoms were defined by the Fourier synthesis method. Positional and thermal parameters were refined by the full matrix least-squares method (on F2) to convergence .

Supplementary material has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (No. 1032292; deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk or http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Photocatalytic Activity Test

The photocatalytic reactions were performed by a typical process [12]: the complex (25 mg) was dispersed in 100 mL aqueous solution of RhB (6 mg L−1), under UV lamp. Before turning on the Hg lamp (400 W), the mixture containing RhB and title compound was magnetically stirred in the dark for 30 min till an adsorption–desorption equilibrium was established. Then 5 mL samples were taken out regularly from the photocatalytic reactor and centrifuged immediately for separation of any solid. The transparent solution was tested for UV measurement.

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structures of the Complex

The crystal of the complex belongs to monoclinic crystal system, space group P2(1)/c. The bismuth atom in the compound adopts distorted pyramidal geometries. Each Bi atom is coordinated by five atoms, namely, two sulphur atoms from –S2CNR2, a carbon atom from benzene ring and two chlorine atoms. C atom of benzene ring is located in the apical position of the pyramidal structure, and S(1), S(2), Cl(1), Cl(1)#1 atoms occupy the bottom positions of the pyramidal structure (Fig. 1). In the complex, the bond angles of C(6)–Bi(1)–S(1), C(6)–Bi(1)–S(2), C(6)–Bi(1)–Cl(1) are 90.1°, 93.2°, and 88.7°, which are not 90°. Therefore their structures are distorted pyramidal geometries. In the complex, the bond length of Bi(1)–S(1), Bi(1)–S(2), C(1)–S(1), C(1)–S(2) is 2.638, 2.667, 1.74 and 1.73 Å. It indicates that the atoms S(1)and S(2) are coordinated to the central atom Bi. The molecular structure of the complex is shown in Fig. 2. Key crystallographic data and X-ray experiment details and selected bond lengths and bond angles are shown in Tables 1 and 2. Furthermore a 1D zigzag chain structure is got by a bridging chlorine atom to link metal ions and 2D network structure is formed by C–H⋯C interactions (Figs. 3, 4).

Photocatalytic Activity

It is well known that some metal–organic complexes (MOCs) could be used as green photocatalysts for the removal of organic pollutants from water [13, 14]. During the photocatalytic process of MOCs, UV–Vis light induces organic ligands to produce X-metal (X = N, O, S) charge transfer by promoting an electron from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO). The HOMO strongly demands one electron to return to its stable state. Therefore, one electron was captured from water molecules, which were oxygenated into the ·OH active species, to complete the photocatalytic process [15–17]. RhB is the most common organic dyes in waste water [18, 19], therefore it was selected as model pollutant to investigate its degradation in the presence of the complex in this work. The photocatalytic behaviors of the complex in RhB solution are shown in Fig. 5. The absorbance peaks of RhB solution decreased obviously along with the reaction time at the presence of the complex. The degradation ratios of RhB are 23.38 % for 10 min, 47.71 % for 20 min, 58.80 % for 30 min, 88.47 % for 40 min and 92.72 % for 50 min of UV irradiation (Fig. 6). The color change photograph of RhB solution is shown in Fig. 7. These results demonstrate that the complex is an excellent photocatalyst for degradation of RhB solution [20–28].

Conclusion

In summary, we synthesized an organobismuth (V) dithiocarbamate complex, [PhBiS2CN(C2H5)2Cl]n and analyzed its structures by the single crystal X-ray diffraction. The complex crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system, space group P2(1). Further we studied the photocatalytic activity of the complex and the results show that the complex exhibits excellent photocatalytic activity in the degradation of RhB solution.

Acknowledgments

This research was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China to C. F. Bi (No. 21371161).

elements.content: A organobismuth (V) dithiocarbamate complex, [PhBiS2CN(C2H5)2Cl]n has been synthesized and characterized by IR, element analysis, 1H NMR and X-ray diffraction single crystal analysis. The complex crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system, space group P2(1)/c. is coordinated by two sulphur atoms, a carbon atom from benzene ring and two chlorine atoms. The complex leads to one-dimensional zigzag chain structure by a bridging chlorine atom to link metal ions and two adjacent chains are bridged by C–H⋯C interactions. elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A organobismuth (V) dithiocarbamate complex, [PhBiS2CN(C2H5)2Cl]n has been synthesized and characterized by IR, element analysis, 1H NMR and X-ray diffraction single crystal analysis. The complex crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system, space group P2(1)/c. is coordinated by two sulphur atoms, a carbon atom from benzene ring and two chlorine atoms. The complex leads to one-dimensional zigzag chain structure by a bridging chlorine atom to link metal ions and two adjacent chains are bridged by C-H⋯C interactions. Furthermore, the photocatalytic experiments of the complex on degradation of rhodamine B (RhB) manifest that the complex is good candidate for the photocatalytic degradation of RhB.

elements.content: Bismuth complex chemistry has attracted significant interest not only due to the low cost and high abundance of bismuth resources on Earth, but also because this element and its compounds find many practical applications in pharmaceutics and medicine [1], catalysis [2], and as precursors for ceramics, superconductors and semiconductors, ionic batteries materials, photocatalysts, etc. [3–5]. For dithiocarbamate ligand with strong coordination ability. It can almost coordinate with all of the transition metal, so a large number of transition-metal complexes with dithiocarbamate have been synthesized and structurally characterized, and a few reports have appeared on the synthesis and structures of the bismuth complexes with dithiocarbamate [6–10]. However, the chemistry of organobismuth (V) complexes with dithiocarbamate has been scarcely studied.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Bismuth complex chemistry has attracted significant interest not only due to the low cost and high abundance of bismuth resources on Earth, but also because this element and its compounds find many practical applications in pharmaceutics and medicine [1], catalysis [2], and as precursors for ceramics, superconductors and semiconductors, ionic batteries materials, photocatalysts, etc. [3-5]. For dithiocarbamate ligand with strong coordination ability. It can almost coordinate with all of the transition metal, so a large number of transition-metal complexes with dithiocarbamate have been synthesized and structurally characterized, and a few reports have appeared on the synthesis and structures of the bismuth complexes with dithiocarbamate [6-10]. However, the chemistry of organobismuth (V) complexes with dithiocarbamate has been scarcely studied.

elements.content: So it causes our interest in organobismuth (V) complexes. A organobismuth (V) complex has been synthesized by the reaction of Ph3BiCl2 with Na(S2CNR2) and characterized by IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, 1H NMR and single crystal X-ray diffraction. In addition, photocatalytic experiments of the complex on degradation of rhodamine B (RhB) were also investigated.

Experimental

Measurement and Reagents

All solvents were pretreated to get rid of the water before using. Sodium diethyldithiocarbamate dihydrate and triphenylbismuth dichloride were purchased from TCI and the other chemicals were produced in China.

elements.content: Infrared spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a Nicolet 170SX spectrometer in the 4000–400 cm−1 region. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a model 2400 Perkin Elmer analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on an AVANCE III (600 MHz) spectrometer. The X-ray diffraction data were collected on an Enraf–Nonius CAD-4 X-ray single-crystal diffractometer. The UV spectra were recorded on an Avatar 360 FT-IR spectrometer in the range 190–600 nm in methanol solution. The fluorescence spectra were recorded on an F-4500 spectrophotometer. Electrochemical study used the CHI650D electrochemical analyzer.

elements.content: Sodium diethyldithiocarbamate dihydrate (0.342 g, 2.0 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (20 mL) and Triphenylbismuth (0.511 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in THF (20 mL)and added. The mixed solution was stirred at 25 °C for 24 h. The mixture was dried in vacuo and extracted by ethanol (10 mL) and dichloromethane (10 mL). The extract was concentrated to 5 mL and crystallization for 2 weeks at 25 °C gave colorless single crystals. Elemental Anal Calc (%) for the complex : C 28.10, H 3.20, N 2.98. Found (%): C 28.06, H 3.15, N 2.95. IR (KBr, cm−1): 1595 (m), 1465 (s), 1246, 1130 (m), 958, 549, 441 (s). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 600 MHz) δ (ppm): 1.46 (d, 6H), 2.84 (d, 4H), 7.85 (m, 5H).
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

Synthesis of [PhBiS2CN(C2H5)2Cl]n

Sodium diethyldithiocarbamate dihydrate (0.342 g, 2.0 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (20 mL) and Triphenylbismuth (0.511 g, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in THF (20 mL)and added. The mixed solution was stirred at 25 °C for 24 h. The mixture was dried in vacuo and extracted by ethanol (10 mL) and dichloromethane (10 mL). The extract was concentrated to 5 mL and crystallization for 2 weeks at 25 °C gave colorless single crystals. Elemental Anal Calc (%) for the complex : C 28.10, H 3.20, N 2.98. Found (%): C 28.06, H 3.15, N 2.95. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1595 (m), 1465 (s), 1246, 1130 (m), 958, 549, 441 (s). 1H NMR (DMSO-d6, 600 MHz) δ (ppm): 1.46 (d, 6H), 2.84 (d, 4H), 7.85 (m, 5H).

elements.content: The single crystal with dimensions of 0.23 × 0.15 × 0.08 mm was mounted on an Enraf–Nonius CAD-4 X-ray single-crystal diffractometer. All data were collected at 293 (2) K with a graphite-monochromatized MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using a ω − 2θ scan mode. 2969 Reflections intensities with I > 2σ(I) was considered to be observed and used in the subsequent refinements. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [11]. The non-hydrogen atoms were defined by the Fourier synthesis method. Positional and thermal parameters were refined by the full matrix least-squares method (on F2) to convergence .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination

The single crystal with dimensions of 0.23 × 0.15 × 0.08 mm was mounted on an Enraf-Nonius CAD-4 X-ray single-crystal diffractometer. All data were collected at 293 (2) K with a graphite-monochromatized MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using a ω - 2θ scan mode. 2969 Reflections intensities with I > 2σ(I) was considered to be observed and used in the subsequent refinements. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 [11]. The non-hydrogen atoms were defined by the Fourier synthesis method. Positional and thermal parameters were refined by the full matrix least-squares method (on F2) to convergence .

elements.content:
Supplementary material has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (No. 1032292; deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk or http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Photocatalytic Activity Test

The photocatalytic reactions were performed by a typical process [12]: the complex (25 mg) was dispersed in 100 mL aqueous solution of RhB (6 mg L−1), under UV lamp. Before turning on the Hg lamp (400 W), the mixture containing RhB and title compound was magnetically stirred in the dark for 30 min till an adsorption–desorption equilibrium was established. Then 5 mL samples were taken out regularly from the photocatalytic reactor and centrifuged immediately for separation of any solid. The transparent solution was tested for UV measurement.

Photocatalytic Activity Test

The photocatalytic reactions were performed by a typical process [12]: the complex (25 mg) was dispersed in 100 mL aqueous solution of RhB (6 mg L-1), under UV lamp. Before turning on the Hg lamp (400 W), the mixture containing RhB and title compound was magnetically stirred in the dark for 30 min till an adsorption-desorption equilibrium was established. Then 5 mL samples were taken out regularly from the photocatalytic reactor and centrifuged immediately for separation of any solid. The transparent solution was tested for UV measurement.

elements.content: The crystal of the complex belongs to monoclinic crystal system, space group P2(1)/c. The bismuth atom in the compound adopts distorted pyramidal geometries. Each Bi atom is coordinated by five atoms, namely, two sulphur atoms from –S2CNR2, a carbon atom from benzene ring and two chlorine atoms. C atom of benzene ring is located in the apical position of the pyramidal structure, and S(1), S(2), Cl(1), Cl(1)#1 atoms occupy the bottom positions of the pyramidal structure (Fig. 1). In the complex, the bond angles of C(6)–Bi(1)–S(1), C(6)–Bi(1)–S(2), C(6)–Bi(1)–Cl(1) are 90.1°, 93.2°, and 88.7°, which are not 90°. Therefore their structures are distorted pyramidal geometries. In the complex, the bond length of Bi(1)–S(1), Bi(1)–S(2), C(1)–S(1), C(1)–S(2) is 2.638, 2.667, 1.74 and 1.73 Å. It indicates that the atoms S(1)and S(2) are coordinated to the central atom Bi. The molecular structure of the complex is shown in Fig. 2. Key crystallographic data and X-ray experiment details and selected bond lengths and bond angles are shown in Tables 1 and 2. Furthermore a 1D zigzag chain structure is got by a bridging chlorine atom to link metal ions and 2D network structure is formed by C–H⋯C interactions (Figs. 3, 4).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures of the Complex

The crystal of the complex belongs to monoclinic crystal system, space group P2(1)/c. The bismuth atom in the compound adopts distorted pyramidal geometries. Each Bi atom is coordinated by five atoms, namely, two sulphur atoms from -S2CNR2, a carbon atom from benzene ring and two chlorine atoms. C atom of benzene ring is located in the apical position of the pyramidal structure, and S(1), S(2), Cl(1), Cl(1)#1 atoms occupy the bottom positions of the pyramidal structure (Fig. 1). In the complex, the bond angles of C(6)-Bi(1)-S(1), C(6)-Bi(1)-S(2), C(6)-Bi(1)-Cl(1) are 90.1°, 93.2°, and 88.7°, which are not 90°. Therefore their structures are distorted pyramidal geometries. In the complex, the bond length of Bi(1)-S(1), Bi(1)-S(2), C(1)-S(1), C(1)-S(2) is 2.638, 2.667, 1.74 and 1.73 Å. It indicates that the atoms S(1)and S(2) are coordinated to the central atom Bi. The molecular structure of the complex is shown in Fig. 2. Key crystallographic data and X-ray experiment details and selected bond lengths and bond angles are shown in Tables 1 and 2. Furthermore a 1D zigzag chain structure is got by a bridging chlorine atom to link metal ions and 2D network structure is formed by C-H⋯C interactions (Figs. 3, 4).

elements.content: It is well known that some metal–organic complexes (MOCs) could be used as green photocatalysts for the removal of organic pollutants from water [13, 14]. During the photocatalytic process of MOCs, UV–Vis light induces organic ligands to produce X-metal (X = N, O, S) charge transfer by promoting an electron from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO). The HOMO strongly demands one electron to return to its stable state. Therefore, one electron was captured from water molecules, which were oxygenated into the ·OH active species, to complete the photocatalytic process [15–17]. RhB is the most common organic dyes in waste water [18, 19], therefore it was selected as model pollutant to investigate its degradation in the presence of the complex in this work. The photocatalytic behaviors of the complex in RhB solution are shown in Fig. 5. The absorbance peaks of RhB solution decreased obviously along with the reaction time at the presence of the complex. The degradation ratios of RhB are 23.38 % for 10 min, 47.71 % for 20 min, 58.80 % for 30 min, 88.47 % for 40 min and 92.72 % for 50 min of UV irradiation (Fig. 6). The color change photograph of RhB solution is shown in Fig. 7. These results demonstrate that the complex is an excellent photocatalyst for degradation of RhB solution [20–28].
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Activity

It is well known that some metal-organic complexes (MOCs) could be used as green photocatalysts for the removal of organic pollutants from water [13, 14]. During the photocatalytic process of MOCs, UV-Vis light induces organic ligands to produce X-metal (X = N, O, S) charge transfer by promoting an electron from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO). The HOMO strongly demands one electron to return to its stable state. Therefore, one electron was captured from water molecules, which were oxygenated into the ⋅OH active species, to complete the photocatalytic process [15-17]. RhB is the most common organic dyes in waste water [18, 19], therefore it was selected as model pollutant to investigate its degradation in the presence of the complex in this work. The photocatalytic behaviors of the complex in RhB solution are shown in Fig. 5. The absorbance peaks of RhB solution decreased obviously along with the reaction time at the presence of the complex. The degradation ratios of RhB are 23.38 % for 10 min, 47.71 % for 20 min, 58.80 % for 30 min, 88.47 % for 40 min and 92.72 % for 50 min of UV irradiation (Fig. 6). The color change photograph of RhB solution is shown in Fig. 7. These results demonstrate that the complex is an excellent photocatalyst for degradation of RhB solution [20-28].

The complex crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system, space group P2(1). Further we studied the photocatalytic activity of the complex and the results show that the complex exhibits excellent photocatalytic activity in the degradation of RhB solution.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we synthesized an organobismuth (V) dithiocarbamate complex, [PhBiS2CN(C2H5)2Cl]n and analyzed its structures by the single crystal X-ray diffraction. The complex crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system, space group P2(1). Further we studied the photocatalytic activity of the complex and the results show that the complex exhibits excellent photocatalytic activity in the degradation of RhB solution.
